doc.after: The oldest settlement in the urban area of Zagreb was a Roman town of Andautonia, now Å Äitarjevo, which dates back to the 1st century AD.[7] The first recorded appearance of the name Zagreb is dated to 1094, at which time the city existed as two different city centers: the smaller, eastern Kaptol, inhabited mainly by clergy and housing Zagreb Cathedral, and the larger, western Gradec, inhabited mainly by farmers and merchants. Gradec and Zagreb were united in 1851 by ban Josip JelaÄiÄ, who was credited for this, with the naming the main city square, Ban JelaÄiÄ Square in his honour.[8] During the period of former Yugoslavia, Zagreb remained an important economic centre of the country, and was the second largest city. After Croatia declared independence from Yugoslavia, Zagreb was proclaimed its capital.[9]
